title: Quiz 3: The Cardiorespiratory System
description: Covers heart anatomy, circulatory routes (systemic, pulmonary, fetal), blood vessels, and the respiratory tract (upper, lower, lungs, pleura).

questions.question: Which chamber of the heart pumps blood into the Pulmonary Trunk?
questions.explanation: The Right Ventricle pumps deoxygenated blood into the pulmonary trunk to go to the lungs. The Left Ventricle pumps to the aorta.
questions.hint: It pumps blood to the lungs for oxygenation.

questions.question: Match the heart valve to its correct location:
questions.explanation: Tricuspid is on the right (Try to be Right); Bicuspid/Mitral is on the left. Semilunar valves guard the exits to major arteries.
questions.hint: Mitral has two flaps (Bi-cuspid).

questions.question: Select all the correct characteristics of Arteries.

options.text: Carry blood AWAY from the heart
Have a thicker Tunica Media than veins

questions.explanation: Arteries carry blood away from the heart and have thick muscle walls. Veins have valves. Pulmonary arteries carry *deoxygenated* blood, so 'always' is false.
questions.hint: Artery starts with 'A' for Away. Exceptions exist for oxygen content.

questions.question: Trace the flow of air through the conducting portion of the respiratory system:
questions.explanation: Air flows from Nose -> Pharynx -> Larynx -> Trachea -> Bronchi -> Terminal Bronchioles. Respiratory zone starts after terminal bronchioles.
questions.hint: From outside to deep inside the lungs.

questions.question: What is the specific function of the Foramen Ovale in fetal circulation?

options.text: Shunts blood from Right Atrium to Left Atrium

questions.explanation: The Foramen Ovale is a hole between the atria that shunts blood from Right to Left, bypassing the non-functional lungs. The Ductus Arteriosus connects vessels.
questions.hint: It is an 'oval' hole between the upper chambers.

questions.question: The trachea bifurcates into the right and left ___BLANK___ bronchi at an internal ridge called the ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: The trachea divides into Primary (Main) Bronchi. The Carina is the ridge at the bifurcation, sensitive to irritants (cough reflex).
questions.hint: The ridge name sounds like 'Karen'.

questions.question: The Left Lung has three lobes, while the Right Lung has two lobes.
questions.explanation: False. The **Right Lung** has **3 lobes** (Superior, Middle, Inferior). The **Left Lung** has **2 lobes** to accommodate the heart.
questions.hint: The heart takes up space on the left side.

questions.question: Review the table on Lung Gross Anatomy. Which feature corresponds to the Right Lung?

richContent.content:
FeatureDescription
AHas a cardiac notch
BDivided by Oblique & Horizontal fissures
CLonger and narrower

questions.explanation: The Right Lung (Feature B) has both Oblique and Horizontal fissures (3 lobes). The Left Lung (A) has a cardiac notch. Left lung is longer; Right is shorter/wider.
questions.hint: Right lung is heavier and has more sections.

questions.question: What is the name of the double-walled sac that surrounds and protects the heart?
questions.explanation: The Pericardium is the fibro-serous sac enclosing the heart. It has fibrous and serous layers.
questions.hint: 'Peri-' means around, '-cardium' means heart.

questions.question: Which muscles assist in ACTIVE or FORCED respiration (Inhalation/Exhalation)?
questions.explanation: Diaphragm and External intercostals are primary for inhalation. Internal intercostals and Abdominals assist in forced exhalation.
questions.hint: Think of muscles in the chest wall and belly.

questions.question: Match the blood vessel layer to its primary tissue composition:
questions.explanation: Intima is the inner lining (endothelium). Media is the muscle layer (control diameter). Adventitia is the outer tough covering.
questions.hint: Media is in the 'middle' and involves muscle.

questions.question: The respiratory zone of the lungs includes the terminal bronchioles.
questions.explanation: False. Terminal bronchioles are the *end* of the conducting zone. The respiratory zone begins at the **Respiratory Bronchioles**.
questions.hint: Conducting = transport only; Respiratory = gas exchange.

questions.question: Which vessel carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus?
questions.explanation: The **Umbilical Vein** carries oxygenated blood *toward* the fetal heart. Umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood away.
questions.hint: In fetal circulation, the vein carries the 'good' blood, just like pulmonary veins.

questions.question: What happens to the Ductus Arteriosus after birth?

options.text: It becomes the Round Ligament of the Liver

questions.explanation: The Ductus Arteriosus constricts and becomes a fibrous cord called the Ligamentum Arteriosum. The Foramen Ovale becomes the Fossa Ovalis.
questions.hint: Arteriosus -> Arteriosum.

questions.question: Which of the following are functions of the Lymphatic System?

options.text: Return excess interstitial fluid to bloodstream

questions.explanation: Lymphatics drain fluid, transport fats (lacteals), and house immune cells. Pumping blood is cardiac; sweating is integumentary.
questions.hint: Think 'Drainage', 'Defense', and 'Dietary fats'.

questions.question: The right lung is separated into lobes by two fissures: the ___BLANK___ fissure and the ___BLANK___ fissure.
questions.explanation: The Right Lung has an Oblique fissure (separating middle/inferior) and a Horizontal fissure (separating superior/middle). Left lung only has Oblique.
questions.hint: One is slanted, one is flat.

questions.question: Where is the Apex of the heart located?
questions.explanation: The Apex (tip) of the heart points downwards and to the left, located at the 5th intercostal space.
questions.hint: It is where you feel the apical heartbeat most strongly.

questions.question: The trachea is supported by complete O-shaped cartilage rings to prevent collapse.
questions.explanation: False. Tracheal cartilages are **C-shaped** (incomplete posteriorly). The posterior gap is bridged by the trachealis muscle to allow the esophagus to expand during swallowing.
questions.hint: If they were O-shaped, swallowing food would be difficult.

questions.question: Which vessel drains blood from the heart muscle itself into the Right Atrium?
questions.explanation: The Coronary Sinus collects deoxygenated blood from the cardiac veins and drains it directly into the Right Atrium.
questions.hint: It is the main vein of the heart's own circulation.

questions.question: Order the path of a drop of blood starting from the Right Atrium:
questions.explanation: Blood flows from RA -> Tricuspid -> RV -> Pulmonary Valve -> Pulmonary Arteries -> Lungs.
questions.hint: Follow the flow through the right side of the heart.
